awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.  The title of the project for this fellowship to Katrina Morgan is " Global analysis of waves on asymptotically flat backgrounds."  The host institution for the fellowship is Northwestern University, and the sponsoring scientist is Jared Wunsch.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research studied wave propagation and decay in the context of different spacetime geometries that arise in General Relativity. The PI established an explicit relationship between the rate at which a geometry becomes flat and the rate at which waves decay on the spacetime. This work established connections between different tools and techniques from different areas of mathematical analysis. The PI also developed novel techniques for studying solutions to the wave equation on another class of spacetimes known as cosmic string spacetimes. These geometries were theorized by the physicist Kibble in the 1970s and questions regarding their existence are an active area of physics research. These geometries are flat away from a singularity at the spatial origin and exhibit a surprising geometric feature in which closed timelike curves are present. Previously existing techniques were not amenable to investigating even basic questions of existence of solutions owing to these closed timelike curves. This work generated four publications. 

The PI 1) organized and ran two iterations of Girls Talk Math; 2) founded and organized the Association for Women in Mathematics Mentor Network at Northwestern University; 3) organized events for the Women in Mathematics group at Northwestern University; 4) served as a reader for undergraduate student Alain Kangabire's senior thesis on the spectral theory of the Laplace operator on metric graphs; 5) organized the Amateur Microlocal Zoom Seminar for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and early career researchers in microlocal analysis across the country during the COVID-19 lockdown; and 6) mentored three students in the Causeway bridge program at Northwestern University.
